candidates.name: Charlotte Littlewood
candidates.why_elect: Director of Port Taranaki, on the Council of WITT and a chartered member of the Institute of Directors. I run my own business, and have a background in policy and regulation, having advised to the NZ and UK Governments. I've a degree in economics and a Masters in Finance.
candidates.why_stand: We live in a truly special region. It must be one the generations of tomorrow can enjoy, as much as we can today. If re-elected, I'll continue to advocate for our rivers being clean for swimming and our natural habitat thriving.

candidates.name: Elvisa Van Der Leden
candidates.why_elect: Contracting for government and non-government organizations has taught me the value of consultation, collaboration and communication. A background in marine science and media studies has led to over 5 years volunteering and working professionally in environmental science education and advocacy—all relevant to the works of regional council.
candidates.why_stand: Taranaki is a uniquely beautiful region—from the mountain to the sea—but there is still a lot of work to be done. In this rapidly changing world, I want to represent the diverse voices of Taranaki and support evidence-based decision making.

candidates.name: Bob Waugh
candidates.why_elect: I have extensive governance and management experience through involvement in community groups in Taranaki including New Plymouth Yacht Club, ESOL, Rotary, Trustee of Central School and NPGHS. I believe my strengths are seeing the bigger picture and innovation which I developed through my business servicing the oil and gas industry.
candidates.why_stand: In my life Taranaki has become the best place to live in NZ. I want our community to have the opportunities I had to be successful. I believe we need productive economic growth, recognising climate change, to protect our environment, enable infrastructure to maintain and grow our prosperity and lifestyle.

candidates.name: Rusty Kane
candidates.why_elect: I have been involved with local and national politics since 1997 first supporting Doug Wilson's protest walk from New Plymouth to Wellington, collected 56,000 signatures for a petition calling for the then Governor-General to impose a snap election. I then formed The People's Choice officially registered on 14 May 1999.
candidates.why_stand: After completing my OE, I looked around for the best place to live, work, and raise a family. New Plymouth ticked all the boxes. Having plentiful job opportunities, affordable housing, superb recreational facilities, civic pride, and a real sense of "can do" attitude.
